data.title: SailPoint seeks up to $11.48 billion valuation in US IPO
data.description:
SailPoint is targeting a valuation of up to $11.48 billion in its initial public offering in the United States, the cybersecurity firm said on Tuesday.

Private equity-backed companies are expected to lead the charge in the IPO market as sponsors look to unload holdings and return capital to investors.

SailPoint is offering 47.5 million shares in the IPO, while its parent, private equity firm Thoma Bravo is offering 2.5 million shares priced between $19 and $21 each to raise up to $1.05 billion.

Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs are the lead underwriters.

SailPoint will list on the Nasdaq under the symbol "SAIL."

data.title: DA Davidson Downgrades United Parcel Service to Neutral From Buy/Add, Cuts Price Target to $116 From $154
data.description: United Parcel Service has an average rating of overweight and mean price target of $133.11, according to analysts polled by FactSet.

data.title: Health insurer Centene beats profit estimates on strength in commercial plans
data.description:
Centene beat Wall Street estimates for fourth-quarter profit on Tuesday, helped by strength in its commercial health insurance plans.

The company mostly focuses on government-backed Medicaid plans for low-income people, as well as income-based government-subsidized health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare.

It has relied on growth in its private plans for individuals and families as it struggles with a drop in members in its government-backed Medicaid plans for lower-income groups, and a rise in costs related to those plans after the end of a pandemic-era federal policy.

For the quarter, Centene reported a medical loss ratio — the percentage of premiums spent on medical care — of 89.6%, compared with 89.5% a year ago. Analysts on average had estimated a ratio of 89.95%, according to data compiled by LSEG.

On an adjusted basis, the health insurer reported a profit of 80 cents per share, above analysts' average estimate of 49 cents.

data.title: The 10-Point: The Wall Street Journal's Guide to the Day's Top News
data.description:
By Emma Tucker

President Trump's U-turn on some tariffs stunned markets and boardrooms across the world, underscoring his willingness to risk major economic disruptions to make a point. Just as new U.S. tariffs of 10% on China went into effect, Beijing retaliated. European leaders are prepared for their own fight with Trump over the world's most valuable trading relationship — and they prefer cooperation. And in Washington, Elon Musk's push to dismantle multiple federal agencies has lawmakers and government workers wondering who is really in charge.

Today's Headlines

China hit back against new U.S. tariffs with a series of moves including levies on certain American goods, an antitrust probe into Google and restrictions on Chinese exports of key minerals.

The White House whipsawed over the timing of tariffs and the possibility of carve-outs before striking last-minute deals with Canada and Mexico.

European leaders, bracing for a trade fight with Trump, said they are ready to strike back but prefer cooperation.

As Musk moved with Silicon Valley velocity to shake up Washington, Trump hinted that there are curbs to keep him from doing anything in the government without the White House's blessing.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio said El Salvador offered to accept deportees of any nationality from the U.S., including incarcerated American citizens.

Live From The Markets

Trump's detente with Mexico and Canada validates optimists on Wall Street, but this risks breeding complacency regarding a real trade war, writes Jon Sindreu.

Read It Here First

Amazon, king of online retail, can't seem to make its physical stores work.

The company has shrunk its portfolio of Amazon Go convenience stores by about half since early 2023, and closed dozens of its other branded retail stores in recent years, including bookstores, fashion outlets and its "4-star" locations stocked with bestselling items from its website. After a decadelong experiment with bricks-and-mortar stores, Amazon's dominance online has yet to translate into a successful strategy for connecting with shoppers in the real world, Kate King reports.

In 24 hours, one senator flipped from no to a crucial yes on Pete Hegseth.

The night before Sen. Thom Tillis cast the fateful 50th "yes" vote to confirm Hegseth as defense secretary, he approached the Senate's new Republican leader and told him he was a "no." That set off a last-minute blitz by the president, the vice president, the Republican whip team and Hegseth himself. Tillis's turnaround left witnesses who came forward as collateral damage, Lindsay Wise, Jack Gillum and Meridith McGraw report.

Expert Take

Q: Is USAID closing?

Rubio notified lawmakers Monday that he intends to work with Congress to reorganize the U.S. Agency for International Development and potentially merge much of it into the State Department. Hours earlier, Musk's Department of Government Efficiency sought to exert control over USAID and shut its headquarters to agency officials. Michael R. Gordon, Ken Thomas and Alexander Ward explain where that leaves the agency.

A: It is unclear how Rubio's promise to work with lawmakers to overhaul USAID would be reconciled with Musk's stated determination to close the agency. In his note to lawmakers, Rubio, who says he is now USAID's acting director, said he asked for a review of the agency's activities and that if some of the agency's bureaus were merged into the State Department, the rest might be abolished.

Trump administration officials have been considering plans to merge the 10,000-person, $40 billion agency into the State Department, which would rein in its autonomy. Democratic lawmakers say that would be illegal without congressional approval, as USAID's existence is in federal statute.

Rubio has already ordered a freeze on most foreign aid as part of a review. He later exempted "core life saving programs" that involve medicine, medical services, food and shelter. The immediate fate of other programs, which include those that support economic development, counterterrorist training, counternarcotics cooperation and efforts to strengthen the rule of law abroad, was left unclear.

Meanwhile, two Democratic senators, Brian Schatz of Hawaii and Chris Van Hollen of Maryland, vowed to place holds on Trump's State Department nominees unless the administration's attack on USAID ends.

See The Story

Trump's tariff idol, William McKinley, abandoned his own tariff policy.

Trump often cites the 25th president, William McKinley, as an inspiration. The "McKinley Tariffs" were some of the largest hikes in U.S. history, but in his second term, McKinley changed his mind, and argued for more free trade.

Happening Today

The Labor Department will report on December job openings at 10 a.m. ET.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will meet with President Trump. The future of the precarious Gaza cease-fire is expected to dominate much of the closed-door discussion.

Earnings: Alphabet, Merck, PepsiCo, AMD, Amgen, Pfizer, KKR, Spotify, PayPal, Chipotle, Mondelez, Prudential

Number Of The Day:

338

The average weight in pounds of the Philadelphia Eagles offensive linemen that will take on the Kansas City Chiefs in the Super Bowl. It's the heaviest — and with an average height of 6-foot-6, the tallest — offensive line in the game's history.

And Finally...

South Koreans are hooked on divorce shows — even as fewer marriages are actually ending.

While not wholly taboo in socially conservative South Korea, divorce hasn't been normalized either. That's left a curiosity void to fill for TV shows, online testimonials and social-media creators.

data.title: Oaktree Specialty Lending's Fiscal Q1 Adjusted Net Investment Income, Revenue Fall
data.description:
Oaktree Specialty Lending reported fiscal Q1 adjusted net investment income Tuesday of $0.54 per diluted share, down from $0.57 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $0.53.

Total investment income for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was $86.6 million, compared with $98 million a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected revenue of $90.4 million.

data.title: Centene's Q4 Adjusted Earnings, Total Revenue Rise; Maintains 2025 Earnings Guidance
data.description:
Centene reported Q4 adjusted earnings Tuesday of $0.80 per diluted share, up from $0.45 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $0.49.

Total revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was $40.81 billion, compared with $39.46 billion a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $39.36 billion.

The company maintained its 2025 adjusted diluted EPS guidance floor of greater than $7.25. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect $7.21.

data.title: Earnings Flash (SPOT) Spotify Technology Posts Q4 EPS 1.76 Euros, vs. FactSet Est of 1.99 Euros
Ball Q4 Comparable Earnings Rise, Sales Decline; Issues 2025 Profit Growth Guidance
data.description:
Ball reported Tuesday Q4 comparable earnings of $0.84 per diluted share, up from $0.78 per share a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $0.80 per share.

Sales for the quarter ended Dec. 31 were $2.88 billion, down from $2.9 billion a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $2.91 billion.

The company said it is "positioned" to grow comparable diluted earnings per share in excess of 10% in 2025.

data.title: Ohsho Food Service's Nine-Month Profit Slides Nearly 8%
data.description:
Ohsho Food Service recorded a 7.5% decline in attributable profit for the nine months ended Dec. 31, 2024, to 5.21 billion yen from 5.63 billion yen in the year-ago period, a Jan. 31 bourse filing said.

Basic earnings per share was 92.16 yen for the three quarters, down from 99.74 yen in the corresponding period of the last fiscal year.

The restaurant chain operator's net sales rose 7.8% to 81.4 billion yen in the nine months from 75.5 billion yen a year prior.

The company expects an attributable profit of 7.97 billion yen, a basic EPS of 141.16 yen per share, net sales of 109.9 billion yen, and a year-end dividend of 25 yen per share for the fiscal year ending March 31.

data.title: North American Morning Briefing: Trump Tariffs: China Hits Back With U.S. Penalties
data.description:
OPENING CALL

Stock futures declined on Tuesday as China struck back against U.S. tariffs with levies on certain American goods, an antitrust probe into Google and restrictions on Chinese exports of key minerals.

The moves escalated a new trade war between the world's two largest economies.

Just after American tariffs of 10% on China went into effect early Tuesday morning, Beijing said it would retaliate. Its measures will go into effect on Feb. 10.

Trump said the tariffs on China were just "an opening salvo." He added: "If we can't make a deal with China, then the tariffs would be very, very substantial."

Premarket Movers

Clorox reported a 15% drop in fiscal second-quarter sales to $1.69 billion, and said it now expects fiscal-year sales to fall 1% to 2%. Shares were down 1.3%.

Kyndryl Holdings swung to a profit in its fiscal third quarter and raised its 2025 guidance. The stock declined 1.7%.

Shares of Nvidia were rising 0.7%. It declined 2.8% on Monday as Wall Street gauged the potential effects of the Trump administration's tariffs on chip companies and amid continued worries over AI advancements made by China's DeepSeek.

Palantir Technologies shares rose 18% after it reported strong sales growth and said demand for artificial-intelligence products keeps growing.

Investors worry that new tariffs on China and the end of "de minimis exemptions" for small packages could hit PDD Holdings' Temu business. PDD stock ticked up.

Super Micro Computer rose 6%. It said it would be providing a fiscal second-quarter "business update" on Feb. 11.

Synaptics fell 5% after announcing CEO Michael Hurlston would be stepping down to become chief executive and president of Lumentum. Lumentum shares rose 1.7%.

Watch For:

Factory Orders for December; Job Openings & Labor Turnover Survey for December; Earnings from Alphabet, Merck & Co., Mondelez, PepsiCo, Pfizer; Fedspeak from Raphael Bostic, Mary Daly

Today's Top Headlines/Must Reads:

- A U.S.-EU Trade War Would Threaten World's Richest Economic Relationship

- Apple Escaped Tariffs Last Time. This Time, It May Have to Raise Prices.

- Alphabet Earnings Could Provide Answers on AI and Cloud Concerns

MARKET WRAPS

Forex:

The dollar fell after Trump delayed tariffs on Canada and Mexico for one month, but uncertainty remains and this could soon lift the safe-haven dollar once more, Commerzbank said.

There is a risk of new tariff announcements coming at any time, Commerzbank said.

"The next shock is bound to come, and this will probably be dollar-positive again."

Key U.S. economic data this week--including ISM data on services Wednesday and monthly jobs data Friday--will also likely lift the dollar as long as they underpin the story of a resilient U.S. economy, it said.

The euro remained under pressure as tariff risks remained heightened even after Trump agreed to pause tariffs on Canada and Mexico, Danske Bank said.

Tariff headlines will likely remain the primary driver of price action in the coming weeks, with a risk of Trump announcing measures against Europe, it said.

Still, Trump looks to be using tariff announcements "primarily as a negotiating tool" and this could help the euro to recover back into a $1.04-$1.05 range.

"We believe Trump is ultimately likely to under-deliver on maintaining tariffs for an extended period," Danske Bank said.

Energy:

Oil prices fell more than 1% as immediate concerns over supply disruptions eased after Trump paused tariffs on Mexico and Canada, the country's biggest foreign suppliers of crude.

Meanwhile, Beijing announced its decision to retaliate with a 15% tariff on U.S. coal and liquefied natural gas imports and a 10% levy on American crude oil and agricultural machinery, starting Monday.

The move raised fears of a trade war that could ultimately hurt global growth and dampen demand, putting further pressure on prices.

Metals:

Gold futures slid, correcting after Canada and Mexico made a deal that will postpone U.S. tariffs by at least a month, but ING said uncertainty over trade should keep the price relatively well supported.

Tariffs on China are proceeding. Investors sought out safe havens in Monday's session though the stronger dollar provided significant headwinds, likely capping an even stronger rally, ING said.

Total known gold ETF holdings have risen more than 590,000 ounces to 83.4 million ounces in the year to date in the flight to safety, ING added.

Comex gold futures' bullish technical setup has strengthened, based on the daily chart, RHB Retail Research said.

Despite selling pressure overnight, the latest price movements show the commodity found strong support at the $2,800 level, leaving its bullish bias intact, RHB said.

The relative strength index is trending upward, signaling a resumption of the bullish path toward the $2,900 level, it said.

The 20- and 50-day simple moving averages are also curving upward, reinforcing the bullish technical setup, RHB added.

TODAY'S TOP HEADLINES

KKR Raises Offer Price for Fuji Soft in Bid to End Takeover Battle

KKR raised its tender-offer price for Japanese software company Fuji Soft in an attempt to end the takeover battle with rival Bain Capital.

The U.S. investment company bought a more than one-third stake in Fuji Soft in November and has said it is best positioned to work with the company to take it private.

AMD Reports Earnings Today. The Outlook Is a Worry.

The outlook for revenue will be investors' focus when Advanced Micro Devices reports its fourth-quarter earnings after the close Tuesday.

The consensus forecast among analysts is that AMD will report December quarter revenue of $7.5 billion with adjusted earnings per share of $1.08. For the current quarter, the consensus call is that revenue will be $7.0 billion and earnings per share will come in at 95 cents, according to FactSet.

Pfizer Is About to Report Its Earnings. The Stock Has Been Floundering.

When CEO Albert Bourla presents Pfizer's financial results on Tuesday morning, investors will be looking for any sign of a turnaround after another year of underperformance.

Pfizer shares fell nearly 50% from the start of 2023 through the end of 2024, while the S&P 500 climbed just over 50%. A Pfizer shareholder has halved her money over that period, while missing out on a shot at historic gains.

XRP, Bitcoin Prices Slide. Why China's Trump Tariffs Standoff Is Hitting Cryptos.

Bitcoin was struggling for direction Tuesday as investors weighed up how President Donald Trump's trade policies will affect cryptocurrency prices.

The world's largest token climbed when Trump paused plans for 25% tariffs on goods from Mexico and Canada, then slid after China said it would hit back with levies of its own.

Asia Markets Jittery as Traders Gauge First Trade War Salvos

Markets across Asia began the day with a relief rally after the U.S. struck last-minute deals with Mexico and Canada to delay tariffs, but the mood took a turn when no such reprieve materialized for China, which hit back with new tariffs on the U.S.

The news poured cold water on hopes that there would be talks between Washington and Beijing that could also lead to a postponing of the 10% tariffs on all Chinese goods entering the U.S.

Netanyahu, Trump to Hold Talks on Gaza Cease-Fire and Wider Middle East Strategy

WASHINGTON-The future of the precarious Gaza cease-fire is expected to dominate much of the closed-door discussion when President Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu meet in the Oval Office Tuesday.

A commitment from Netanyahu to negotiate an extension and potentially a long-term cessation of hostilities would give Trump a diplomatic win, and could secure the release of remaining hostages, including some Americans.

El Salvador Offers to Take U.S. Deportees of Any Nationality Including Imprisoned Americans

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador-U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio said on Monday that El Salvador has offered to accept deportees of any nationality from the U.S., including incarcerated American citizens who would be held in the country's maximum-security prison.

El Salvador President Nayib Bukele offered to "house in his jails dangerous American criminals in custody in our country," Rubio said in San Salvador, the second stop on his first foreign trip, after meeting with Bukele. "No country has ever made an offer of friendship such as this," he said, calling it the "most unprecedented and extraordinary, extraordinary migratory agreement anywhere in the world."

Trump Hints at Curbs on Musk's Powers After Billionaire Shakes Up Washington

WASHINGTON-President Trump on Monday said there were curbs in place to prevent Elon Musk from doing anything in the government without the White House's blessing, responding to growing confusion about who was overseeing Musk's push to dismantle multiple agencies.

Trump described Musk's role as advisory. "Elon can't do-and won't do-anything without our approval and we'll give him the approval where appropriate. Where not appropriate, we won't," Trump said.

Write to ina.kreutz@wsj.com TODAY IN CANADA

data.title: Machinery Cyclical Stock Likely Most Affected by U.S Tariffs — Market Talk
data.description: Machinery cyclical stock would be the most affected by U.S tariffs in the capital-goods sector, Deutsche Bank Research analyst Gael de-Bray says in a research note. Most industrial companies that have reported so far beat expectations on orders and revenue. The downturn in manufacturing activity that began in 2022 was just starting to show signs of easing, de-Bray says. However, the uncertainty, extra costs and inflation brought forth by new U.S tariffs could derail this nascent industrial recovery, the analyst says. With the risk of a global recession rising, Swedish SKF and Sandvik are likely first in line to feel the impact. (nina.kienle@wsj.com)

data.title: Record Wins for Linde’s Small On-Site Solutions in 2024 Driven by Electronics and Decarbonization
data.description:
WOKING, UK / ACCESS Newswire / February 4, 2025 / Linde announced today that for the fifth successive year, it secured a record number of new small on-site projects for the supply of nitrogen and oxygen. During 2024, the company signed 59 new long-term agreements for which it will build, own and operate 64 plants at customer sites.

Linde signed agreements with customers across a broad range of end markets, with demand driven by secular growth in electronics, including battery production for electric vehicles, plus glass and metal manufacturers seeking ways to reduce their emissions and improve efficiency.

These projects will leverage Linde's proprietary ECOVAR® technology, which is engineered for exceptional efficiency, adaptability and reliability. They meet Linde's strict investment criteria and, due to their short execution timelines, will rapidly contribute to the company's growth. Additionally, they will continue to enhance Linde's network density.

"Linde's unwavering commitment to innovation is reflected in our leading-edge technology portfolio, which is best positioned to meet the evolving needs of our customers," said Sanjiv Lamba, Chief Executive Officer, Linde. "Our small on-site plants fully leverage this and provide cost-effective solutions that help our customers enhance efficiency while reducing emissions."

About Linde

Linde is a leading global industrial gases and engineering company with 2023 sales of $33 billion. We live our mission of making our world more productive every day by providing high-quality solutions, technologies and services which are making our customers more successful and helping to sustain, decarbonize and protect our planet.

The company serves a variety of end markets such as chemicals & energy, food & beverage, electronics, healthcare, manufacturing, metals and mining. Linde's industrial gases and technologies are used in countless applications including production of clean hydrogen and carbon capture systems critical to the energy transition, life-saving medical oxygen and high-purity & specialty gases for electronics. Linde also delivers state-of-the-art gas processing solutions to support customer expansion, efficiency improvements and emissions reductions.

For more information about the company and its products and services, please visit linde.com.

Contacts:

Investor Relations

Juan Pelaez

Phone: +1 203 837 2213

Email: juan.pelaez@linde.com

Media Relations

Anna Davies

Phone: +44 1483 244705

Email: anna.davies@linde.com

SOURCE: Linde plc

data.title: Estee Lauder expands restructuring plan with 7,000 job cuts, posts sales beat
data.description:
Estee Lauder on Tuesday expanded its restructuring plan that would include up to 7,000 job cuts and posted smaller-than-expected drop in second-quarter sales.

Shares of the company, which fell about 49% last year, were marginally down in premarket trading.

The company said that the expanded plan is to help Estee Lauder return to sales growth and restore a solid double-digit adjusted operating margin over the next few years along with the aim to "manage external volatility, such as potential tariff increases globally."

As part of its turnaround efforts to drive profit recovery, the company has been implementing restructuring programs, which include a series of changes in the executive team after Stéphane de La Faverie took on the role of Chief Executive Officer in January.

Estee Lauder expects to take restructuring and other charges of between $1.2 billion and $1.6 billion, before taxes, consisting of employee-related costs, contract terminations, asset write-offs, and other costs associated with implementing these initiatives.

The company's sales fell 6% to $4 billion in the quarter, compared with analysts' estimates of 7.3% drop to $3.97 billion, as per data compiled by LSEG.

data.title: India's Budget Plots Path for Sustainable Growth
data.description:
By Kimberley Kao and Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

India's budget delivered on several items markets had been hoping for: a lowered deficit target, tax cuts, and support for the country's factories and the middle class. Focus now turns to policy execution, with economists watching to see if policymakers can deliver on their aim of supporting growth without sacrificing fiscal prudence or financial stability.

Here's what we watched:

FISCAL FOCUS: The 50.65 trillion rupee budget for the fiscal year starting April, equivalent to $584.22 billion, stuck to its fiscal consolidation guns, despite pressure to do more to lift the economy.

India again cut its fiscal deficit target, lowering it to 4.4% of gross domestic product from an estimated 4.8% for the current fiscal year ending March.

Fiscal prudence prevailed over calls to spur growth, ANZ economists said.

With policymakers continuing to prioritize macroeconomic resilience over short-term spurts of growth, the budget shows continued focus on strengthening public sector balance sheets to "create a long runway of high and stable growth," Goldman Sachs economists Santanu Sengupta, Arjun Varma and Andrew Tilton said.

The budget targets what Nomura economists view as an "impossible fiscal trinity" of fiscal discipline, income tax cuts and steady capex outlay. "Only two can hold."

DOWNSIZE DEBT: The budget also laid out a medium-term fiscal strategy to keep central government debt on a downward path to 50% of GDP by FY 2031.

Increased confidence that the government can stick to that framework and keep debt on the decline would be positive for India's sovereign rating over time, said Jeremy Zook, primary sovereign analyst for India at Fitch Ratings. "Still, the pace of debt reduction is gradual, which leaves open downside risks from a large economic shock."

While India is likely to reach its near-term policy goals, Christian de Guzman, senior vice president at Moody's Ratings, doesn't expect the debt burden to improve enough to put its fiscal strength on par with most of its investment-grade peers.

GROWTH DRIVERS: The budget identified four key engines of development: agriculture, micro, small and medium enterprises, private sector investments and exports. Measures included financial assistance for farmers, expanded credit for startups, and job creation for manufacturing.

The budget is largely neutral for economic growth, and is unlikely to deliver any inflationary impulse, according to Nomura economists led by Sonal Varma.

Given the time it will take to see the impact on consumption, OCBC maintains its real GDP growth forecast for FY 2026 at 6.2%.

TAXES: To boost consumption, the budget tabled income tax relief aimed at freeing up spending power but analysts are not fully sold on the efficacy.

The government raised the income tax exemption limit for annual incomes up to INR1.2 million, specifically targeting the middle class. That will result in a revenue loss of about INR1 trillion in direct taxes.

The tax cuts could raise net incomes among India's upper middle class by 2%-7%, analysts at Emkay Global said, but the "net effect is inconspicuous."

ANZ economists expect to see only a mild boost to household consumption, as the direct impacts seem limited to a narrow base. Consumption could have been boosted more widely by reducing indirect taxes on essential goods like fuel, they said.

OCBC economist Lavanya Venkateswaran noted that there are no clear offsets to compensate for the revenue loss and though there is a shift toward greater tax compliance, implementation will be key. Reliance on nontax revenues leaves fiscal consolidation vulnerable given the uncertainty of such sources, while tax revenue assumptions depend on a growth outlook subject to downside risks, she added.

MARKETS: The implications for markets appear largely neutral, with analysts viewing the budget as a tailwind for consumer-facing stocks.

Yuan Yiu Tsai at Eastspring Investments flags urban consumption-related stocks as budget winners over capex-driven ones as they can benefit from the boost to disposable income. Immediate beneficiaries include auto, hospitality and retail stocks, the portfolio manager said.

Goldman Sachs strategists also favor consumer-retail oriented lenders, banks and financial firms, as well as urban-discretionary consumption categories.

RBI RESCUE? Eyes now turn to the Reserve Bank of India meeting Friday--its first under a new governor. The budget's fiscal consolidation has firmed up expectations that a rate cut is coming after GDP data signaled that India's growth slowed to a four-year low.

With a paring back of the fiscal deficit likely to impart a negative fiscal impulse on the economy, the task of lifting growth likely rests on the RBI, HSBC economists said.

Write to Kimberley Kao and Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

data.title: BOE Could Cut Rates Only Twice More, Pausing in Second Half of 2025 — Market Talk
data.description: The Bank of England could cut interest rates only twice more, including once at this week's meeting, pausing rate reductions by the second half of the year, Berenberg's Andrew Wishart says in a note. Concerns about weak growth and rising unemployment rate are likely to result in faster initial rate reductions, but fears about a rebound in U.K. inflation could then cause the BOE to pause, he says. "Rising government spending and rate cuts will encourage demand and allow firms to cover higher costs by raising prices." Berenberg expects U.K. inflation could reaccelerate to 3.0% in 2025. U.K. money markets price in three rate cuts this year, though a second reduction isn't fully priced in until June. (miriam.mukuru@wsj.com)

data.title: Ingredion Reports Strong 2024 Fourth Quarter and Full-Year Results
data.description:
Ingredion Incorporated, a leading global provider of ingredient solutions to the food and beverage manufacturing industry, has released its fourth quarter and full-year 2024 results. The company reported strong financial performance, driven by robust sales volume growth and strategic reorganization efforts.

Financial Highlights

Ingredion's full-year 2024 reported and adjusted earnings per share (EPS) were $9.71 and $10.65, respectively, compared to $9.60 and $9.42 in 2023. The company generated $1,436 million in cash from operations, benefiting from a $400 million favorable change in working capital balances as corn costs decreased. Additionally, Ingredion returned $426 million to shareholders, including $216 million in share repurchases.

Business and Operational Highlights

The company saw record fourth-quarter financial results, with significant contributions from the Texture and Healthful Solutions (T&HS) segment and the Food and Industrial Ingredients (F&II) segments in the US/CAN and LATAM regions. The T&HS segment experienced double-digit sales volume growth, while the F&II US/CAN segment benefited from multi-year customer contract renewals, leading to substantial operating income growth.

Strategic Initiatives and Corporate Developments

Ingredion's strategic initiatives included a $100 million investment in its Indianapolis facility to enhance reliability and operating efficiency. The company also completed the sale of its South Korea business, which impacted net sales and operating income. Despite these changes, Ingredion managed to achieve significant cost savings through its Cost2Compete program.

Management's Perspective

Jim Zallie, president and CEO of Ingredion, highlighted the company's record Q4 financial results and the successful reorganization efforts that positioned the company for future growth. Zallie emphasized the importance of customer collaboration and operational excellence in driving the company's performance.

Future Outlook

Looking ahead to 2025, Ingredion expects reported and adjusted EPS to be in the range of $10.75 to $11.55. The company anticipates low single-digit growth in net sales, driven by greater volume demand, partially offset by price mix and foreign exchange impacts. Operating income is expected to increase by mid-single digits, with specific growth projections for the T&HS and F&II LATAM segments.

SEC Filing: Ingredion Inc [ INGR ] - 8-K - Feb. 04, 2025

data.title: Corvel 4Q Rev $228.0M >CRVL
Corvel 4Q EPS 46c >CRVL
CorVel Announces Revenues and Earnings
data.description:
FORT WORTH, Texas, Feb. 04, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) — CorVel Corporation announced the results for the quarter ended December 31, 2024. Revenues for the quarter were $228 million, an increase from $202 million in the December quarter of 2023. Earnings per share for the quarter were $0.46, compared to $0.33 in the same quarter of the prior year. Revenues for the nine months ended December 31, 2024 were $664 million, an increase from $588 million during the nine months ended December 31, 2023. Earnings per share for the nine months ended December 31, 2024 were $1.32, compared to $1.09 during the nine months ended December 31, 2023. The earnings per share numbers for the current and prior year have been adjusted to reflect the three-for-one stock split of its common stock which was paid on December 24, 2024.

Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2025 Highlights 

  • Revenue increased 13% to $228 million, compared to the third quarter of fiscal year 2024.
  • Gross profit increased 25% to $52.9 million, at 23.2% gross margin, compared to the third quarter of fiscal year 2024 gross profit of $42.2 million.
  • Diluted earnings per share increased 39% to $0.46, compared to the third quarter of fiscal year 2024 diluted earnings per share of $0.33.
  • Exited the quarter with $163 million cash, cash equivalents, and no borrowings.
  • The Company repurchased $9.6 million of common stock during the quarter.

A key to CorVel’s success and differentiation in technological innovation is the development team’s structure, the depth and tenure of the employees, and the lack of impedance in translating business needs into the development and implementation of functioning systems. Due to the depth and strength of the IT team, system updates, and new features are released weekly, which enables rapid progress on enhancements and advancements in automation and innovation. In the December quarter, generative-AI-based functionality was released to streamline document processing and identify claim milestones, and improvements are planned to enhance the integrated communication platform. These enhancements can optimize outcomes, improve the experience of injured workers, and make day-to-day tasks easier, which allows CorVel professionals to focus on higher-level activities.

During the quarter in the healthcare market, the persistent upward trend of medical costs is causing Administrative Services Only, ASO, customers to seek additional medical savings and greater cost efficiency in claims. CERIS is ideally equipped to solve the growing demand by offering multiple audits and lowering claim thresholds. With substantial expertise in prepay, CERIS is able to accommodate ASOs and Payers with the tools needed to reduce medical spend without additional administrative overhead.

Safe Harbor Statement under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995

All statements included in this press release, other than statements or characterizations of historical fact, are forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are based on the Company’s current expectations, estimates and projections about the Company, management’s beliefs, and certain assumptions made by the Company, and events beyond the Company’s control, all of which are subject to change. Such forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, improved productivity resulting from automation and augmentation across enterprise business systems. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future results and are subject to risks, uncertainties and assumptions that could cause the Company’s actual results to differ materially and adversely from those expressed in any forward-looking statement results of operations and financial condition is greater than our initial assessment. The risks and uncertainties referred to above include but are not limited to factors described in this press release and the Company’s filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including but not limited to “Risk Factors” in the Company’s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended March 31, 2024, and the Company’s Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarters ended June 30, 2024 and September 30, 2024. The forward-looking statements in this press release speak only as of the date they are made. The Company undertakes no obligation to revise or update publicly any forward-looking statement for any reason.

data.title: Amcor plc Files 8K - Operations And Financial Condition >AMCR
data.description:
Amcor plc (AMCR) filed a Form 8K - Operations and Financial Condition - with the U.S Securities and Exchange Commission on February 04, 2025.

On February 4, 2025, Amcor plc (the "Company") issued a press release regarding financial results for the second quarter and first six months of fiscal year 2025. The press release is furnished as Exhibit 99.1 hereto. The Company is also furnishing an investor presentation relating to the second quarter and first six months of fiscal year 2025 (the "Presentation"), which will be used by management for presentations to investors and others. A copy of the Presentation is attached hereto as Exhibit 99.2 and incorporated into this Item 2.02 by reference. The Presentation is also available on the Company's website at https://www.amcor.com/investors. The Company is not including the information contained on its website as part of, or incorporating it by reference into, this Current Report on Form 8-K.

The information in this Current Report on Form 8-K shall not be deemed "filed" for purposes of Section 18 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the "Exchange Act"), or incorporated by reference in any filing under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the "Securities Act"), or the Exchange Act, except as shall be expressly set forth by specific reference in such a filing.

The full text of this SEC filing can be retrieved at: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1748790/000174879025000005/amcr-20250204.htm

Any exhibits and associated documents for this SEC filing can be retrieved at: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1748790/000174879025000005/0001748790-25-000005-index.htm

Public companies must file a Form 8-K, or current report, with the SEC generally within four days of any event that could materially affect a company's financial position or the value of its shares.

B2 Impact is one of the leading pan-European debt management companies. B2 Impact offers solutions to the challenges created by defaulted loans, and provide liquidity to financial institutions, contributing to a healthier financial system. B2 Impact promote lasting financial improvement through transparent and ethical debt management. B2 Impact is headquartered in Oslo, Norway and the B2 Impact share is listed on the Oslo Stock Exchange under the ticker "B2I". For further information, visit www.b2-impact.com

data.title: Arc Minerals, Anglo American JV Extends Copper Mineralization at Zambian Project
data.description:
Arc Minerals' joint venture company with Anglo American's (, AGL.JO) Zambian subsidiary on Tuesday reported additional near-surface copper mineralization 1.5 kilometers from Cheyeza East Oxide Occurrence in Zambia.

The diamond drilling at Cheyeza intersected mineralization including a 40.6 meter section averaging 0.61% copper from 22.25 meters, including 7.70 meters at 1.72% copper from 26.75 meters or 12.75 meters at 1.20% copper from 22.25 meters.

The exploration company said it was now exploring the extent of sulfide mineralization at Cheyeza by identifying additional drill targets.

data.title: Earnings Flash (INGR) INGREDION INCORPORATED Reports Q4 Revenue $1.80B, vs. FactSet Est of $1.86B
U.K. Grocery Inflation Slows as Supermarkets Bet on Discounts, Report Says
data.description:
By Michael Susin

U.K. grocery inflation fell in January as intense promotional activity provided some relief for budget-pressured households.

Annual grocery inflation fell to 3.3% for the four weeks to Jan. 26 compared with the previous year. This followed 3.7% grocery inflation recorded in December, according to the latest report from research firm Kantar.

Kantar said take-home grocery sales rose by 4.3% on year, and nearly one third of this spending was on promotions.

Consumers are also ditching brand names and prioritizing keeping costs down, with private-label sales proportionally reaching a record high of more than half of sales in January.

Following the Christmas festivities and related excesses, January's sales were also marked by an increase in wellness trends, with more than 10% of the average consumer's bill spent on fresh staples such as fruit, vegetables and salad.

Sales of low-and-no alcohol drinks were 7% higher than the same period a year prior, as the "dry January" trend becomes increasingly popular among older shoppers.

Among the top-performing grocers over the 12 weeks to Jan. 26, sales of the German discounter Lidl rose 7.4% and reached three consecutive years of growth, holding a market share of 7.2%.

Online retailer Ocado was the fastest-growing grocer for the ninth consecutive month, with sales up 11.3% and a 1.9% market share.

The U.K.'s largest grocer, Tesco, achieved a market share of 28.5% and saw a 5.6% rise in sales.

Write to Michael Susin at michael.susin@wsj.com
